newsitem.title: NETHERLANDS: Vietnam urged to add value to coffee production.
newsitem.headline: Vietnam urged to add value to coffee production.

text.p: Vietnam should seek to add value to its coffee production and expand further into the arabica sector, Dutch agri-bank Rabobank said.

"To guarantee a constant quality of the coffee, substantial investments in harvesting techniques and processing facilities are a must. With the present undercapitalisation of most Vietnamese companies, the industry will have to rely heavily on foreign investors," a study on the country's agribusiness said.
The report noted that some inroads had been made by western firms into the sector, but Rabobank said most had been cautious.

Britain's E.D. and F. Man and New York-based McCullagh are involved in upgrading coffee processing in the province of Dulak, and Switzerland's Nestle SA is setting up a plant to produce instant coffee for domestic and export markets.
Exports have risen sharply in the past five years, showing an annual growth of more than 120 percent, making coffee one of the country's major foreign currency earners.
Rabobank said the relatively young tree population would take another five years to reach peak production and that further export growth was likely.
The government objective is to expand area from a current 155,000 hectares to about 260,000 ha in 2000, which should give an output of 250,000 tonnes.
By the same date, the government aims to raise the cultivated area devoted to arabica to 20 percent from five, mainly in the north. Rabobank noted the variety fetched higher prices on world markets.
The country also had to tackle a negative image problem arising out of defaults.

Rabobank said a number of foreign coffee traders are allowed to export coffee through a Vietnamese trader with a certified export licence. These foreign enterprises are Germany's Neuman, Switzerland's Volcafe and Thailands JF Trading.
"Confidence in the Vietnamese market is becoming more and more important, indeed critical in keeping its position in relation to Indonesia, its major competitor," the report said.
